stem: A client is 12 hours post-total thyroidectomy for Graves' disease. Based on the documentation in the Post-Surgical Endocrine Surveillance Log, which intervention is the highest priority?

options.text: Administer IV propranolol and initiate cooling measures.
Assess the back of the neck for post-operative hemorrhage.

rationale.correct: The client is exhibiting signs of thyroid storm, a life-threatening surge of thyroid hormone often triggered by surgery or physical trauma. Key indicators include high fever (104.8째F), severe tachycardia (164 bpm), and agitation/delirium. The highest priority is to block the systemic effects of the hormone using beta-blockers (propranolol) and to lower the dangerously high temperature. Untreated thyroid storm can lead to heart failure and death within hours.
clinicalPearls: Thyroid storm is characterized by rapid and elevated physiological processes.
Treatment often involves the 'P' drugs: Propranolol (to manage heart rate), PTU (to block thyroid hormone production), and Prednisone (steroids to inhibit T4 to T3 conversion).
Avoid aspirin in thyroid storm as it can displace thyroid hormone from proteins, potentially worsening the crisis.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: While assessing the neck for hemorrhage post-thyroidectomy is important, a temperature of 104.8째F and a heart rate of 164 bpm are indicative of thyroid storm, not hemorrhage. Prioritize interventions addressing the thyroid storm.

mnemonic.title: Storm-Stop
mnemonic.expansion: Fever high? Heart fly? Storm is nigh. Give the propranolol to the guy.

exhibits.title: Nursing Physical
exhibits.content: Current: Client is extremely agitated and confused. Profuse diaphoresis noted. Cardiac monitor shows atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR). Lungs are clear.

exhibits.title: Serum Trends
exhibits.content:
Admission: TSH < 0.01 (Low). Free T4 (High).
Note: Surgery involved significant manipulation of the thyroid gland.
